sentence.text: Patient 1 was a 3310 g (90th centile) female infant born to a then 36-year-old G4P2á3 at 37 2/7 weeks gestation via cesarean for breech presentation.
The pregnancy was complicated by prenatal ultrasound demonstrating craniosynostosis and polyhydramnios leading to suspicion for Crouzon syndrome.
At birth, she required immediate intubation.
Physical exam and imaging confirmed pansynostosis resulting in a cloverleaf skull as well as proptosis and shallow orbits.
Cutis gyrata was appreciated on her forehead and in the preauciular regjon (Fig. 1).
Postnatal retrospective examination of the prenatal 3D ultrasound images revealed irregularities of the scalp which were similar in appearance to the rugations of her cutis gyrata.
There was also a paucity of scalp hair.
A hemangiomatous skin tag was noted on her chest, as well as, a prominent umbilical stump.
In addition, she had a sacral dimple, rugated labia majora and prominent clitoris.
Based on the physical exam, molecular testing for BSS was sent and otolaryngology, neurosurgery, and plastic surgery consults were requested.
She received a ventricuoperitoneal shunt on the first day of life due to hydrocephalus.
Her hospital course was complicated by choanal stenosis and identification of a TCS on direct laryngoscopy/bronchoscopy.
Based on her poor clinical status with unlikely recovery, care was withdrawn at 8 days of age.
Thereafter, she was found to have c.1707C>G, resulting in p.Tyr375Cys mutation in FGFR2, which has been previously-reported in BSS.
